lines.text: [first lines]
Oh Jack, let's dance, shall we dance? And let's have some more champagne.

[Rhodes has been coming on to her, trying to impress her with a Cary Grant impersonation]
You can't be serious!

[Still doing "Cary Grant" impersonation]
Why, I've never been more serious in my life.
Why are you imitating Tony Curtis?

[Normal voice]
I'm not imitating Tony Curtis, I'm imitating Cary Grant.
You're doing Tony Curtis doing Cary Grant...

[Deflated]
Oh...
Cary Grant doesn't even do "Cary Grant" any more.
It doesn't trouble you that blackmail is, in fact, against the law?
Policemen are constantly breaking the law. It's one of the many ways we have of upholding it.
I have absolutely NO intention of passing on the date of that shipment.
Well, let me put it another way. Do the names Halliday, Hornfield, Kinnersley and Drampton mean anything to you?
Uh, no, I don't follow you.
they are ALL poisonously unpleasant.

[Wavering somewhat]
I'll manage, somehow... Others have.

Yes... Well, let me draw a persuasive little picture for you. Where you will be going, they have the oddest notions of hospitality. First, they shave your head. Then, they delouse you, feed you with something a ravenous crocodile would pass up, then, lock you up for the night with unfriendly lesbian companions - and you have your own "private" little chamber pot under the bed. Oh, it is very unpleasant, I know. That's why I urge you to reflect whether you shouldn't save yourself all that misery, by passing on the date to Mr. Rhodes... Well, take your time. Reflect well.

[after giving it a mere moment of thought]
I've taken my time and I've reflected well.
And?
I've decided to save myself all that misery - I'll pass on the date.
Splendid.
When is it?
You'll get it in a day or two. Run along, now.
a kitten. They're ever such a lot of fun if you strangle them right.
Cyril, hurry up! Your breakfast is getting cold, as usual.

[Cyril enters]
Cyril, I don't like your tie.
You gave it to me, dear.
That's no excuse.

[Handing him the paper]
Cyril, look at the newspaper.

[Uninterested]
Something in it?
The date!

[Sarcastic]
That made the front page again?
It's the 25th - - six more days, and you'll finish at The Yard.
Hopefully in a blaze of glory. My final case - the capstone of my career.

[Chuckles]
Well, what difference would it make?
Oh, it has to do with something sacred.
Cyril, you're making no sense, as usual.
It's about the sanctity of property. Of all the crimes of which man is capable, the one that really rankles me is the violation of property. Oh, there's your murder, of course - - rape, kidnap...

[Looks slyly at his wife]
... wife beating.
Don't be ridiculous.
diamonds. The dearest, noblest, most direct link we have to the very core of the planet itself.
The filthy bugger.
Yes, dear.

[She and Rhodes have disguised themselves as Arabs, and have just cleared airport Customs inspection. Rhodes did his best to sound like an "Arab."]
That was the worst Peter Sellers I have ever heard.
I wasn't doing Peter Sellers - I was doing Peter Sellers doing Omar Sharif!
How much do you want for the diamonds?

[Hesitantly]
Well, um... Would you think that, um, one million dollars is fair?

[pauses]
No... I don't think one million dollars is fair... I think THREE million dollars is fair.
I prefer YOUR definition of "fair."
